lines.text: Life itself is only a vision. A dream. Nothing exists, save empty space and you. And you... are but a thought.
Who are you?
An angel.
What's your name?
Satan.
Uh oh.
What's the matter?
Nothing. Just that it's sure a sorry name for an angel.

[after the Mysterious Stranger wipes out an entire village of clay people]
You murdered 'em!

[face slowly turns into a skull]
Never mind them. People are of no value. We could make more sometime... if we need them.
You look about as disappointed as Presbyterians in Hell!

[Looking at Twain's library]
These must be those classics everyone talks about.
What are classics?
Something everyone wants to have read but don't want to read.
Everyone is a moon, and has a dark side which he never shows to anybody, if he can help it.
There's no sadder sight than a young pessimist. Except an old optimist.
Abel is a good boy, but if Cain had stayed a bear, it would have improved him.
The man with an idea is a fool, until the idea succeeds.
How come you want to catch that comet so bad, Mr. Twain?
Oh-ho-ho, the comet and I are part of the plan, angelfish. No doubt the Almighty said here, "There go those two unaccountable freaks. They came into this world together, they must go out together."
She says things are not right. The buzzard, for instance. She says it was intended to live on decayed flesh. But we cannot overturn the whole scheme to accomodate the buzzard.

[about his son, Cain]
It's not a fish. It must either be an enigma, or some sort of bug. I never had a thing perplex me so. Perhaps I can take it apart to see what its arrangements are.
I will continue on doing my duty, but when I get to the other side, I will use my considerable influence to have the human race drowned again, this time drowned good. No omissions. No ark.
We're only waiting for the right moment now.
What are you talking about?
Yeah?
Becky, do you swear not to tell?
Sure.
On your grandmother's bones?
[Becky rolls her eyes]
Well, do ya?
Yeah.
We're gonna hijack this balloon.
What?
Hijack?
Tom Sawyer, aeronort, saves airborne friends from madman's death wish.
A harp, a hymn book and wings? Good god, what a swindle. I'm led to consider a different path. Heaven for climate, Hell for company.

It looks like a man. I have never seen a man before, but it looks like one. I think it's the most unusual of the reptiles. It has frizzy hair, no hips, and tapers like a carrot, so it must be a reptile, although it could also be architecture.
Stormfield's a man of faith. Means he is willing to believe what he knows ain't so.
Let me see, there are a number of things I want to say to you before I go.
[Clears throat]
Always obey your parents.

[Dark side]
... when they are present.
Be respectful of your superiors.

[Dark side]
... if you have any.
Rise early, for it is the early bird that catches the worm.

[Dark side]
I once knew a man who tried it. Got up at sunrise. Horse bit him.
It's time.

[Dark side]
I'm still considering whether to go. I haven't seen an atom of truth that there is a future life.
Yet I am strongly inclined to expect one. Anyway, don't be such a sissy in the face of a real adventure.
laughter. Against the assault of laughter - ha-ha-ha-ha! - nothing can stand.
Supposing we do die? Is there really a heaven or a hell?
Oh, I don't know about that. I don't wish to express an opinion. You see, I have friends in both places.
What is that?
It's a... valentine.
Valentine? Where did you get that word?
It... looks like a valentine.
It's a good word, and bears repeating.
Don't worry. Providence protects children, and idiots. I know it's true. I've tested it.
Well, Tom and Huck and l, well, see, we're not so sure...

That l know what l'm doing up here? Angelfish, it's just like piloting a river. You get to know the shape of it. Like following a hall at home in the dark. And even if you feel some fear, you know no harm can come to you because you've traveled that hallway a hundred times in nothing but bare feet and faith.

[witnessing two clay men fighting over a clay cow]
I find you humans quite interesting, even though you are a worthless, greedy lot.

[watching a village of clay people hold a funeral]
Fools. What fascinations there are on this planet. Strange mortals with... curious customs. We'll have a storm now. And an earthquake if you like. You must stand aside... out of danger.

[the Mysterious Stranger causes lightning to destroy the clay castle and creates a fissure to get rid of the rubble and all of the remaining clay figures. The fissure closes, and the Mysterious Stranger fills the resulting empty space with grass and flowers]
I can do no wrong... for I do not know what it is.
That? Oh, that was just a little Writer's Block, that's all.
I think a man has to have his own Heaven to be happy.
